items.title: 'We were supposed to grow old together': Fiancée mourns man found day after crash
items.summary_auto: The fiancée of a man who was found dead in the snow after a crash last week in Ottawa is remembering him as a devoted father who worked long hours and came so near to seeing his family again.

items.title: Amazon employees in Canada told about layoffs through premature internal email
items.summary_auto: Amazon on Tuesday appeared to have prematurely alerted Amazon Web Services cloud-computing employees to layoffs planned for Wednesday morning by sending a commiseration email and team-wide meeting invitation hours early.

items.title: B.C. government struck compromise with assisted dying policy, court hears
items.summary_auto: Current and former Ministry of Health officials took the stand this week to describe the origins of the province’s medical assistance in dying policy, which is at the centre of this case. The policy allows publicly-funded, faith-based health-care providers to opt out of providing MAID in their facilities. It also requires them to work with health authorities to ensure an efficient transfer of care in these cases and to facilitate requests for information about MAID.

items.title: Wife of former South Korean president sentenced to 20 months for bribery
items.summary_auto: A South Korean court sentenced former first lady Kim Keon Hee on Wednesday to one year and eight months in jail after finding her guilty of accepting Chanel bags and a diamond pendant from Unification Church officials in return for political favours.

items.title: Alberta’s population could surpass British Columbia’s as early as 2038: StatsCan
items.summary_auto: Alberta could overtake British Columbia as Canada's third most populated province in just over a decade, according to new projections released by Statistics Canada.

items.title: NDP criticizes government hiring of former Sask. Party executive director
items.summary_auto: The Saskatchewan NDP is criticizing the hiring of Patrick Bundrock, the Saskatchewan Party's former executive director, for a new $198,000 a year job with the province's executive council.

items.title: Magnitude 3.7 earthquake rattles southern and central Ontario
items.summary_auto: A 3.7 magnitude earthquake rumbled through parts of central and southern Ontario Tuesday night.

items.title: Federal report examines gaps in RCMP response to N.S. mass shooting
items.summary_auto: A workplace incident report investigated the 2020 mass shooting in Nova Scotia which left RCMP Const. Heidi Stevenson and 21 others dead.

items.title: Millions of Canadian homes have high levels of cancer-causing radon. Is yours one of them?
These Ontario snowbirds are ditching the U.S. and wintering in Mexico
items.summary_auto: Some Ontario residents who typically spend their winters in the U.S. say they’ve recently opted to buy property in Mexico instead. The shift comes as some snowbirds grow uneasy about the political climate under U.S. President Donald Trump.

items.title: This Albertan signed up to fight in Ukraine. He was nearly killed by friendly fire
items.summary_auto: David Rauser spoke to CBC News from western Ukraine after being accidentally shot in the head by a member of his team in Donetsk.

items.title: 5 CAF members quit Women Veterans Council, citing lack of 'real outcomes'
items.summary_auto: Five Canadian Armed Forces members of the Women Veterans Council have quit over what they say is a failure of “institutional conditions needed to enable meaningful, impactful work.”

items.title: Why solving cold case killings just got much harder for police
items.summary_auto: Police cold-case units face a new challenge in solving decades-old killings. With the world's largest storehouse of genealogy information, Ancestry.com, now banning law enforcement from using its data without obtaining a court order, it is much harder for police to build family trees based on crime-scene DNA and zone in on suspects via their distant relatives.

items.title: Brantford, Ont., police won’t collect assault weapons for federal gun buyback program
items.summary_auto: The Brantford Police Service says it won’t participate in collecting assault weapons from the public as part of the federal government’s gun buyback program.

items.title: How are the NDP leadership hopefuls different? Contrasts emerge as they hit membership deadline
items.summary_auto: In a leadership race where candidates have largely been in agreement, candidates are beginning to show New Democrats what sets them apart.

items.title: Why do 3 major diseases disproportionately impact Black Canadians? New genome project aims to find out
items.summary_auto: Researchers in Ontario, Quebec and Nova Scotia are launching a project to map more than 10,000 genomes from Black Canadians with Type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure and an aggressive form of breast cancer. Project leaders hope their findings eventually help target treatment and preventive care and contribute to better health outcomes for racialized patients.

items.title: I used to focus on my patients' health. Now with ICE, I worry about their safety
items.summary_auto: Justin Ho is a Canadian studying dentistry in Minneapolis. He was taught to treat a patient regardless of who they are. After recent events in the U.S., he's realized that health care cannot be disentangled from the politics of the day.

items.title: Man sprays U.S. lawmaker Ilhan Omar with unknown substance at town hall
items.summary_auto: A man sprayed an unknown substance on Democratic U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar and was tackled to the ground Tuesday during a town hall in Minneapolis, where tensions over federal immigration enforcement have come to a head after agents fatally shot an intensive care nurse and a mother of three this month.

items.title: 2 federal agents fired shots when Alex Pretti was killed in Minneapolis: U.S. official
items.summary_auto: Two federal officers fired shots during the encounter that killed ICU nurse Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection official told Congress in a notice sent Tuesday.

items.title: What Minnesotans are saying about Trump's immigration crackdown
items.summary_auto: For days, the people of Minneapolis have been expressing outrage over the shooting death of Alex Pretti at the hands of federal agents. Here's how some of them are reacting to the shooting, as well as what they say about U.S. President Donald Trump's move to send more than 2,000 Immigration Customs and Enforcement officers to Minnesota.

items.title: B.C. man gets 5 months in jail over videos, images posted to Pornhub without consent
items.summary_auto: Judge sentenced the man to five months in custody and 18 months probation, finding the "pre-meditated and revenge motivated nature of the acts" he committed placed it in a more "egregious category" than other cases.

items.title: How do Greenlanders feel about Trump? An impersonator went undercover to find out
items.summary_auto: Mark Critch from This Hour Has 22 Minutes dressed up as Donald Trump and visited Greenland to learn more about how residents feel about the U.S. president. He shares his findings with Power & Politics.

items.title: Mexican president blames Meta labelling failure for her use of fake Ryan Wedding image
items.summary_auto: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum on Tuesday blamed Meta, the parent company of Instagram, for failing to add an AI label to a fake image of Canadian Ryan Wedding that she used during a news conference about the alleged drug kingpin. Sheinbaum is under increasing pressure at home to explain the details of Wedding's arrest after conflicting statements from her government and U.S. authorities.

items.title: Fact check: Is the U.S. now controlling what’s posted on TikTok?
items.summary_auto: After a deal was reached to keep TikTok operating in the U.S., some users accused the app of censoring their posts. CBC’s fact-check team breaks down the facts about the deal.

items.title: Calgary gold retailers see 'huge increase' in business as precious metal prices soar
items.summary_auto: Soaring gold and silver prices have brought people to Calgary precious metal retailers in droves as they look to cash in or buy more. One expert says the future value of precious metals remains uncertain, largely due to geopolitical instability.

items.title: Suspended Edmonton detective should be dismissed for leaking files to CBC: tribunal
items.summary_auto: A suspended detective should be formally dismissed from the Edmonton Police Service for leaking confidential investigative police files to CBC News, says a police disciplinary tribunal.

items.title: Judge temporarily bars removal of boy, 5, and father detained by immigration agents in Minnesota
items.summary_auto: A federal judge has issued a temporary order prohibiting removal of a five-year-old Ecuadorian boy and his father whose arrest last week in Minnesota quickly become another lightning rod for America's divisions on immigration under the Trump administration.

items.title: Canadian doctors say they’re losing 20 million hours a year to unnecessary paperwork
items.summary_auto: Doctors in Canada each spend, on average, nine hours per week on administrative tasks, totaling 42.7 million hours annually across the country, according to a new report from the Canadian Medical Association and the Canadian Federation of Independent Business.

items.title: B.C.'s attorney general urges Canadian businesses to 'think about their role' in supporting ICE operations
items.summary_auto: B.C. billionaire Jim Pattison and Vancouver-based Hootsuite are among the Canadian companies facing backlash for business ties to United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).

items.title: Neil Young gifts Greenland free access to music catalogue
items.summary_auto: Neil Young announced Tuesday on his blog that he is providing free access to his entire music catalogue to residents of Denmark's semiautonomous territory, whose futures have lately become a point of tension between the U.S. and NATO.

items.title: Why Minneapolis has become such a flashpoint amid ICE deployments
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration has deployed federal troops to several U.S. cities in the past year — mostly Democrat-led, mostly under the guise of unsubstantiated claims that illegal immigrants are terrorizing those cities with crime. But Minneapolis has seen the largest troop deployment and the worst violence.

items.title: Ont. lawyer alleges Durham Region police violently assaulted her, dragged her to courthouse cells
items.summary_auto: A lawyer says she was left bloody and swollen after multiple Durham regional police officers allegedly slammed her head on a desk without provocation, ripped off her head scarf and dragged her to the basement cells of the Oshawa courthouse last week.

items.title: France moves to ban social media apps for users under 15 years old
items.summary_auto: French lawmakers approved a bill to ban social media for children under the age of 15. France is the first European country to undergo such a move.
